content: @Kyle Miller I've opened #16018 to revive #14091 as the latter's author has been inactive for over a month

This reviving seems a bit hostile, as it deletes all attribution from the original PR (author line on the header, as well as commit authorship). Besides, isn't #14091 being discussed in #PR reviews > #14091 on digraphs, with the conclusion there being that it's prudent to wait longer?
I've waited long enough
(deleted)
I mean no harm or bad faith on the original author, but one month of inactivity across all GitHub is asking for an explanation
I do not want to disturb the original author and so I opened the other PR to explore things

Jeremy Tan said:

I mean no harm or bad faith on the original author, but one month of inactivity across all GitHub is asking for an explanation

This is vacation time in most of Europe and even in parts of the US. It is unreasonable to expect authors to respond quickly or even respond at all.

Further there is a different series of PRs which are also adding directed graphs with flow problems. I don't see how a nice digraph API is achieved by a third PR doing the same thing. It might help to coordinate with the authors of those PRs even if it takes some time.
Also, I am concerned that although the code appears nearly identical to mathlib4#14091, the original author is not in the author list.
Note that "authors" means "who should I ask for help with this"; it's not for attribution
I don't think that interpretation makes sense when it is combined with the copyright notice.
Further, the authors of a file may not be actively contributing anymore and may be unable to help.
Nevertheless, that's how it's used in mathlib

Ruben Van de Velde said:

Note that "authors" means "who should I ask for help with this"; it's not for attribution

I think this is only half true. For example, I saw a file yesterday (admittedly, it was in Init) with only Leo in the author list. Surely Leo doesn't want to be bothered for help with some boring Init file at the bottom of Mathlib with no use anywhere.

I think "authors" generally means (a) whoever wrote the original code + (b) people who made significant contributions or refactors to the code + (c) people who made some changes here and there, but are heavily involved in this area of the library and hence are good contacts for issues with the file.
Yes. I think the wider open source software world also views it as authorship in some sense.

I guess a more appropriate response would be to try and get a clarification from @Jack Cheverton that they either are, or are not, still working on the PR. Once we have this we can start considering whether a "hostile takeover" is appropriate.

I can take some responsibility for this on behalf of @Jack Cheverton, who is my undergraduate student and thought that the PR was merged. He emailed me this morning to let me know of the thread here, expressing that he is fine if the more experienced folk take over the PR. (He was still not sure if it had been merged.)

So let's assume that the takeover can be made without any fear of hostility. (I might have caught this earlier, sorry, but was out of the country for a couple weeks and followed this up with COVID...fun...)

@Jeremy Tan Creating this separate PR has made things complicated. You have good intentions here for making progress, but the first thing we need to do in these situations is to reach out to the PR author and see what is going on.

Now that we've heard from Jon, I propose we do the following:

  • Let's close your PR @Jeremy Tan, since we shouldn't have two competing PRs if there is nothing wrong with the original one.
  • I will address the comments in #14091 this morning myself and ping some reviewers. The code is originally mine, and Jack was kind enough to work on the material and create a PR.
  • Later we can discuss how to unify some of the material. (It's possible that having SimpleGraph extend Digraph works better than it used to, but there's still an issue that a simple graph isn't a digraph; there's simply a way to regard a simple graph as being a digraph by using pairs of directed edges. I think something close to the class-based solution for inheritance that @Yaël Dillies proposed long ago is probably the right solution.)
Ok, I've just pushed changes to #14091. Maybe @Kim Morrison, @Johan Commelin, or @Yaël Dillies would want to take a look?
Currently behind on requested reviews, but I might get to it tomorrow!
I suggest adding somewhere in the docs that digraphs allow loops, just because some authors consider digraphs to be loopless.
I am sorry for my outburst yesterday. I have added the authors from the first PR back
